docs.lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that health care is a defensive investment. When the overall economy weakens, people still take their medicine and go to the hospital for surgery, so investors tend to favor the stocks of drug companies and hospital chains. But several mutual fund managers say the experience of the last economic downturn has made them question their previous assumptions. The most recent information from Medicare -- showing that billings from hospitals dropped nearly 4 percent in August compared with the year earlier -- is adding to investors' concerns that hospitals' volumes, and therefore revenues, are not impervious to the ebbs and flows of the economy.

headline.main: Rethinking Health Care as a Haven for Investors

docs.abstract: Study of Medicare data has led some analysts to challenge conventional wisdom that health care sector is a safe haven for investors during economic downturns; proponents of view argue that increased economic sensitivity of sector may be result of consumers' need to shoulder increased share of own costs through copayments and deductibles; skeptics contend that sector, while maturing, continues to be valid defensive play and operates independently of economic cycles; many portfolio managers recommend that hospital and drug stocks be analyzed by company fundamentals rather than industry characteristics; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If there was one thing Americans had a right to expect from Congress, it was a federal plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs. It is a promise that has been made again and again -- in particularly high decibels during the last presidential election. The House and Senate have passed bills, and although both are flawed, this page has urged Congress to finish work on them as a first step toward fulfilling this longstanding commitment. Unfortunately, things have changed. The government cannot afford the program now. That is the fault of President Bush and the Republican majorities in the House and Senate. They broke the bank with their enormous tax cuts. The country is facing the largest budget deficit in history, and there is no realistic plan for getting it under control. The limited version of a prescription drug benefit now being considered in Congress would cost about $400 billion over 10 years.
docs.abstract: Editorial says federal government will have to abandon $400 billion plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs because only way to pay for it is through borrowing; says fault lies with Pres Bush and Republican majorities in House and Senate, who have driven up federal budget deficit with their enormous tax cuts; charges that some of these cuts are designed to create deficit that will give Republicans excuse to beat back popular entitlement programs

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress works on legislation to cover prescription drugs under Medicare, lawmakers have been deluged with complaints from retirees who fear losing drug benefits they already have from former employers. Some lawmakers say this issue is emerging as the most immediate threat to the legislation.

headline.main: RETIREES ALARMED AT THREAT OF CUTS IN DRUG BENEFITS

docs.abstract: Some lawmakers say mounting fear of retirees of losing drug benefits they already have from former employers poses most immediate threat to legislation to cover prescription drugs under Medicare; Medicare generally does not cover outpatient prescription drugs, but some employers voluntarily provide such coverage; members of Congress now realize that any Medicare drug benefit they may approve will have profound effect on health coverage provided to retirees by former employers; as result, Congress is frantically seeking ways to address concern, by offering tax credits, subsidies or other incentives for employers to continue providing drug benefits to retirees; about 12 million of 40 million Medicare recipeints have retiree health benefits, usually including some drug benefits; Congressional Budget Office estimates that one-third of people with such drug coverage could lose it under bills pased in June by House and Senate; photo (M)
